key_points: Joseph Rosenbaum, the first person Kyle Rittenhouse shot, was unarmed but had threatened multiple people and chased Rittenhouse before being shot.
Rittenhouse was pursued by protesters after shooting Rosenbaum, leading to additional shootings, including the wounding of Gaige Grosskreutz, who was armed.
The legal discussion in Rittenhouse's trial included confusion over a Wisconsin law regarding minors carrying firearms, specifically the exception for long rifles.
The dismissal of the weapon possession charge against Rittenhouse was based on the specific length of the rifle's barrel.
The article criticizes the presence of a military-style semiautomatic weapon at a volatile protest but acknowledges that Wisconsin law permitted it.
Features of the Rittenhouse trial, such as police officers overlooking him as a suspect due to his appearance, are criticized as indicative of systemic issues in the criminal legal system.
Rittenhouse turned himself in after not being detained on the spot by police officers.
The officers stopped questioning Rittenhouse when realizing he did not understand his Miranda rights, a courtesy often not extended to indigent defendants.
The article implies a discrepancy in treatment by law enforcement based on Rittenhouse's appearance.
The opinion piece suggests that a conviction for Rittenhouse would not address the broader systemic issues within the criminal legal system.
